description.original: Automatically number or re-number headings in an Obsidian document
description.translation: Automatically number or re-number headings in an Obsidian document

dict..log('Number Headings Plugin: Applying h: .log('Number Headings Plugin: Applying headings numbering changes:', changes.length)
dict..log('Number Headings Plugin: Applying t: .log('Number Headings Plugin: Applying table of contents changes:', changes.length)
dict.name: 'Number all headings in document (: name: 'Number all headings in document (and show options)'
dict.name: 'Remove numbering from all heading: name: 'Remove numbering from all headings in document'
dict.text: \"Do you want to save these settin: text: "Do you want to save these settings in the document's front matter?"
dict.text: 'To add numbering to your document: text: 'To add numbering to your document, bring up the command window (on Mac, type CMD+P), and then type "Number Headings" to see a list of available commands.'
dict.text: 'If the document has front matter: text: 'If the document has front matter defined with the below settings, the project-wide settings defined on this screen will be ignored. You can define front matter like this:'
dict.text: ` ---\r\n alias:\r\n - Ex:
text: `    ---
    alias:
    - Example Alias
    tags:
    - example-tag
    number headings: first-level 1, start-at 2, max 6, 1.1, auto, contents ^toc
    ---`
dict.text: `\r\n The 'number headings' f:
text: `
      The 'number headings' front matter key is used to store numbering settings specific to the file. There are four possible options
      in the value to the right of the colon, separated by commas.
    `
dict.text: ` \r\n For example, '1.1:
text: `      
      For example, '1.1' means both top level and other headings will be numbered starting from '1'.
    `
dict.text: ` \r\n For example, 'A.1:
text: `      
      For example, 'A.1' means top level headings will be numbered starting from 'A'.
    `
dict.text: ` \r\n For example, '_.A:
text: `      
      For example, '_.A.1' means top level headings will NOT be numbered, but the next levels will be numbered with letters and numbers.
    `
dict.text: ` \r\n For example, '1.1:
text: `      
      For example, '1.1:' means headings will look like '## 2.4: Example Heading'
    `
dict.text: ` \r\n For example, 'A.1:
text: `      
      For example, 'A.1-' means headings will look like '## B.5- Example Heading'
    `
dict.text: ` \r\n For example, 'I.A:
text: `      
      For example, 'I.A —' means headings will look like '## IV.A — Example Heading' (with Roman numerals)
    `
dict..setText('Yes, save settings in document: .setText('Yes, save settings in document, and automatically number')
dict..setDesc('If selected, numbering will no: .setDesc('If selected, numbering will not be applied to the top heading level.')
dict..setDesc('Start numbering the first head: .setDesc('Start numbering the first heading level from this value.')
dict..setDesc('Defines the numbering style fo: .setDesc('Defines the numbering style for level one headings. Valid values are 1 (for numbers) or A (for capital letters) or I (for Roman numerals).')
.setDesc('Defines the numbering style for headings below level one. Valid values are 1 (for numbers) or A (for capital letters) or I (for Roman numerals).')
dict..setDesc('Defines the separator style be: .setDesc('Defines the separator style between the heading number and the heading text. Valid values are : (colon) or . (dot) or - (dash) or — (emdash) or ) (a right parenthesis). You can also leave it blank for no separator, or have a space before the separator.')
dict..setDesc('Anchor which labels the header: .setDesc('Anchor which labels the header where a table of contents should be inserted. The anchor should be added at the end of a header. For example, ^toc.')
.setDesc('Anchor which labels the headers that should not be numbered. The anchor should be added at the end of a header. For example, ^skipped.')
